title: Five cultural outings to enjoy with a baby in Paris
New museum will honor Art Nouveau genius Hector Guimard in Paris
Is southern France ready for a surge in wildfires?
subhead: France is bracing for a risky summer. The national weather service has classified the Mediterranean arc at 'high' or 'very high' fire alert. While the country has learned lessons from major blazes in 2022, its firefighting aircraft fleet is aging.
byline: By Maryline Baumard and Léa Sanchez

title: Macron discusses migration with Starmer on second day of UK state visit
Paris Saint-Germain crush Real Madrid 4–0 to reach Club World Cup Final against Chelsea
French police raid far-right RN party's HQ over suspected illegal campaign financing
subhead: Investigators are focusing particularly on loans granted by wealthy party members to the Rassemblement National and its candidates, as part of a judicial inquiry opened over suspicions of illegal financing in the far-right party's recent campaigns.
byline: By Laura Motet and Clément Guillou

title: Hamas agrees to partial hostage release in 'difficult' truce talks
subhead: The Islamist group said it would release 10 hostages as part of Gaza ceasefire talks brokered by Qatar. The statement came after the United States signalled its belief that an agreement for a 60-day truce would be struck before the end of the week.

title: Hermès family edges out Bernard Arnault in new ranking of France's richest
subhead: The heirs of Thierry Hermès take the top spot as France's wealthiest family in the yearly ranking established by 'Challenges' magazine. Since 2017, LVMH founder Bernard Arnault and his family had topped the chart.

title: In Bhutan, yaks are in danger in the land of happiness
subhead: 'The Himalayas Overheating' (6/6). In this small country, known for its concept of 'Gross National Happiness,' climate change has had a major impact on the environment and the evolution of lifestyles.
byline: By Bruno Philip (Laya, Thimphu (Bhutan), special correspondent)

How Israel tracked down and assassinated scientists involved in Iran's nuclear program
subhead: Israel's attacks in June killed 16 leading researchers involved in Iran's efforts to develop an atomic bomb. Some of them had been under Israeli intelligence surveillance for two decades. With their deaths, Israel believes it has dealt the most decisive blow yet to Tehran's military nuclear program.
byline: By Louis Imbert, Ghazal Golshiri and Liselotte Mas

title: Tax on ultra-rich: 'France has the opportunity to lead the way,' say Nobel Prize-winning economists
subhead: As public deficits balloon and extreme wealth explode, creating a minimum tax on the assets of billionaires should be a priority, argue seven Nobel Prize-winning economists in an op-ed for Le Monde.

title: Iranian photographer Forough Alaei portrays life during the war: 'Nothing will ever be the same again'
subhead: After the first Israeli bombings in Iran, Iranian photographer Forough Alaei left Tehran to take refuge with her family on the Caspian Sea coast. She documented those days when war plunged them into the unknown.
byline: By Forough Alaei (Photos) and Audrey Delaporte
